message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient collided with another player's knee on the lateral aspect of his knee, which suggests a possible injury to the medial collateral ligament (MCL). The lack of swelling or effusion indicates it is not a major injury, and the lack of laxity on Lachman's and posterior drawer tests rules out ACL and PCL injuries. The increased laxity on valgus stress test compared to the unaffected knee confirms an MCL injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The varus stress test rules out injury to the lateral collateral ligament, and Lachman's and posterior drawer test rule out injury to the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments. The increased laxity on valgus stress test suggests an injury to the medial collateral ligament. The lack of swelling or effusion further supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has intact sensation and strength in both lower extremities, which suggests no injury to the nerves or muscles. The size of the right knee is the same as the left knee without any swelling or effusion, indicating that there is no major ligament tear. The lack of laxity in Lachman's test and posterior drawer test indicates that the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments are intact. The increased laxity upon valgus stress test suggests an injury to the medial collateral ligament. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) medial collateral ligament.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The valgus stress test indicates that the patient has an injury to the medial collateral ligament (MCL), which connects the femur to the tibia on the inner side of the knee joint. The intact sensation and strength in both lower extremities, as well as the firm endpoints on Lachman's and posterior drawer tests, suggest that the other major ligaments (the ACL and PCL) are not injured. The lack of swelling or effusion indicates that there is no significant joint inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury (collision with another player's knee on the lateral aspect) suggests a medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The lack of swelling or effusion and the firm endpoints on Lachman's and posterior drawer tests make it less likely to be an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) or posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The valgus stress test being more lax on the right knee compared to the left suggests an MCL injury on the right knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury is likely to be a medial collateral ligament (MCL) sprain, as valgus stress test is positive and the other tests for anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments are negative. The lack of swelling and intact sensation and strength also suggest a mild injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient's right knee is more lax upon valgus stress test when compared to his left knee indicates that he has injured the medial collateral ligament. There is no laxity on the varus stress test, ruling out injury to the lateral collateral ligament. Lachman's and posterior drawer tests both have firm endpoints without laxity, ruling out injury to the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and findings suggest a medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The lack of swelling or effusion suggests that it is a grade I or II injury. The absence of laxity on Lachman's and posterior drawer tests rules out anterior and posterior cruciate ligament injuries. The increased laxity on valgus stress test suggests an MCL injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lack of swelling or effusion and the negative Lachman's and posterior drawer tests make it less likely that the patient has an ACL or PCL injury. The valgus laxity on the stress test suggests a potential MCL injury, while the intact strength and sensation suggest that there is no nerve damage. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Medial collateral ligament.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The varus stress test examines the medial collateral ligament, which is intact in this case. However, the patient has more laxity on valgus stress test, indicating an injury to the lateral collateral ligament. Lachman's and posterior drawer tests both having firm endpoints without laxity suggests that neither the anterior nor posterior cruciate ligament is injured.
